headline.main: DIRECT LINK FOUND BETWEEN SMOKING AND LUNG CANCER

docs.abstract: Article in journal Science reports discovery of direct scientific link between smoking and lung cancer; finds that chemical found in cigarette smoke causes genetic damage in lung cells that is identical to damage observed in many malignant lung tumors; experts say findings provide long-missing link because they go beyond statistical association, shortfall that has allowed tobacco industry to deny that cigarettes cause cancer; Dr John Minna welcomes 'smoking gun'; researchers from University of Texas Cancer Center and Beckman Research Institute studied effects of cigarette-smoke ingredient on p53 gene, which is vital in suppressing runaway growth of cells; problems with p53 gene are found in up to 70 percent of lung cancers; most of p53 defects in lung cancer occur at three 'hot spots' along DNA molecule (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A team of researchers says it has found a direct scientific link between smoking and lung cancer, a discovery that adds yet another piece to the already substantial evidence that tobacco smoking is a cause of cancer. The findings, published today in the journal Science, report the first evidence from the cell biology level linking smoking to lung cancer. The scientists say a chemical found in cigarette smoke has been found to cause genetic damage in lung cells that is identical to the damage observed in many malignant tumors of the lung.
